SEARCH
Package ca.jolt.injector

Class JoltContainer

java.lang.Object
ca.jolt.injector.JoltContainer
public final class JoltContainer extends Object
The JoltContainer class serves as a lightweight dependency injection container. It is responsible for scanning specified packages to discover bean classes, registering them, managing their instantiation, performing dependency injection, and handling lifecycle callbacks.

Bean Discovery and Registration:
The container scans a given base package for classes annotated with JoltBean. Once discovered, these classes are validated (ensuring they are concrete and have a public no-argument constructor) and then registered. Each bean is identified by a unique name derived either from the value attribute of the JoltBean annotation or, if empty, by a convention that lowercases the first letter of the class's simple name.

Dependency Injection and Lifecycle Management:
When a bean is created, its fields annotated with JoltBeanInjection are automatically populated. The container also ensures that lifecycle methods annotated with PostConstruct and PreDestroy are invoked at the appropriate times. For singleton beans, an instance is maintained and reused upon subsequent requests.

Exception Handling and Circular Dependencies:
The container checks for potential circular dependencies during bean creation and throws a CircularDependencyException if one is detected. If a bean cannot be found or fails to create, BeanNotFoundException or BeanCreationException is thrown, respectively.

Usage Example: 

 JoltContainer.getInstance()
         .scan("com.example.myapp.beans")
         .initialize();

 MyBean bean = container.getBean(MyBean.class);
 // Use the bean...

 JoltContainer.getInstance().shutdown();

Note: This container is designed to be simple and lightweight. It may not include some features found in more comprehensive DI frameworks.

Since:
1.0
Author:
William Beaudin

  • Method Details

    • autoScan

      public JoltContainer autoScan()
      Use reflection to detect the package of the caller class.

      The resulting package is used to scan for beans, at the same level of the class extending JoltContainer. And below it. This function should not be called by the user as it is used internally by the container. For more details on how the package scanning works see scan(String).

      Returns:
      The container instance for method chaining.

    • scan

      public JoltContainer scan(String directory) throws JoltDIException
      Scans the specified base package to discover and register all classes annotated with JoltBean.

      This method converts the package name to a path, retrieves all resources for that path, and then recursively searches directories for class files. For each class file found, the class is loaded and, if it carries the JoltBean annotation, it is validated and registered.

      Parameters:
      directory - the base package to scan for bean classes; must not be null or empty.
      Returns:
      the container instance for method chaining.
      Throws:
      JoltDIException - if the base package is null, empty, not found, or if an error occurs during scanning.

    • initialize

      public void initialize()
      Initializes the container by eagerly instantiating all non-lazy beans that have a singleton scope.

      Upon invocation, this method iterates over the registered bean definitions and, for each bean that is marked as non-lazy and scoped as a singleton, it triggers bean creation. This ensures that these beans are ready for use and that their PostConstruct lifecycle methods are invoked.

      Note: This method can only be called once. After initialization, no further modifications to the bean definitions are permitted.

    • shutdown

      public void shutdown()
      Shuts down the container and releases all resources.

      During shutdown, the container iterates over all managed beans and invokes any lifecycle methods annotated with PreDestroy. After invoking these callbacks, all internal caches, bean definitions, and tracking collections are cleared, effectively resetting the container.

      This method should be called during application shutdown to ensure that resources are properly released and any cleanup logic is executed.

    • getBean

      @Deprecated(since="1.0", forRemoval=false) public <T> T getBean(String name)
      Deprecated.
      This method is not thread-safe and as been marked for removal. You should use getBean(Class) instead.
      Retrieves a bean instance by its registered name.

      If the bean instance already exists (in case of singleton scope), it is returned directly. Otherwise, the bean is created, its dependencies are injected, and any PostConstruct lifecycle callbacks are invoked. The created bean is then stored in the singleton cache (if applicable) and returned.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the expected type of the bean.
      Parameters:
      name - the unique name of the bean to retrieve; must not be null.
      Returns:
      the bean instance corresponding to the given name.
      Throws:
      BeanNotFoundException - if no bean is found with the specified name.
      BeanCreationException - if there is an error during the creation or initialization of the bean.

    • getBean

      public <T> T getBean(Class<T> type)
      Retrieves a bean instance by its type.

      This method searches through all registered bean definitions and returns the first bean whose class is assignable to the specified type. If the bean has already been created (for example, if it is a singleton), the cached instance is returned. Otherwise, the bean is instantiated, its dependencies injected, and its lifecycle callbacks invoked.

      Type Safety: The returned object is cast using type.cast(...) ensuring that the runtime type is checked against the provided class.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the expected type of the bean.
      Parameters:
      type - the class type of the bean to retrieve; must not be null.
      Returns:
      an instance of the bean matching the specified type.
      Throws:
      BeanNotFoundException - if no bean is found that is assignable to the specified type.
      BeanCreationException - if an error occurs during the creation or initialization of the bean.

    • getBeans

      public <T> List<T> getBeans(Class<T> parentType)
      Retrieves a list of beans that are instances of the specified parent type.

      This method searches through all registered bean definitions and returns a list of beans whose classes are assignable to the specified parent type. If no beans are found, an empty list is returned.

      Type Safety: The returned objects are cast using parentType.cast(...) ensuring that the runtime type is checked against the provided class.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the beans to be retrieved
      Parameters:
      parentType - the class object representing the parent type of the beans; must not be null.
      Returns:
      a list of beans that are instances of the specified parent type.
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if the parentType is null.

    • getBean

      public <T> T getBean(Class<T> type, String name)
      Retrieves a bean instance by its type and name.

      This method searches through all registered bean definitions and names to returns the first beans to match the specified type and name. If the bean has already been instantiate (for example, as a singleton) the cached instance is returned. Otherwise, the bean is instantiated, its dependencies injected and its lifecycle callbacks invoked.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the expected type of the bean.
      Parameters:
      type - the class type of the bean to retrieve; must not be null.
      name - the name of the class as value set in the annotation.
      Returns:
      an instance of the bean matching the specfified type and name.
      Throws:
      BeanNotFoundException - if no bean is found that is assignable to the specified type.
      BeanCreationException - if an error occurs during the creation or initialization of the bean.

    • inject

      public <T> T inject(T instance)
      Injects dependencies into fields annotated with JoltBeanInjection in the given object. The object does not need to be a managed bean.

      This method allows dependency injection into objects that are not managed by the container, making it possible to use dependency injection in objects created through other means.

      Type Parameters:
      T - the type of the object
      Parameters:
      instance - the object instance to inject dependencies into
      Returns:
      the same instance after injection
      Throws:
      JoltDIException - if dependency injection fails
